questions.text: An alcoholic was drunk and came to a casualty with semi-consciousness, irrelevant talking, and sweating. When his glucose was measured, it was 30mg/dL. The duty doctor started the patient on glucose, but his symptoms didn't improve. What he should have added to correct hypoglycemia?
questions.explanation:
Solution:

IV thiamine Thiamine acts as a coenzyme for many enzymes in the glycolysis process.

Highyeild:

Clinical evaluation of patients at risk of thiamine deficiency* Clinical history • Weight loss in past year • Reduced Body Mass Index • General clinical impression of patient's nutritional status • High dietary carbohydrate intake • Recurrent episodes of vomiting in past month • Co-occurrence of other nutritionally related conditions (polyneuropathy, amblyopia, pellagra, anemia) Early signs-symptoms of thiamine deficiency • Loss of appetite • Nausea/vomiting • Fatigue, weakness, apathy • Giddiness, diplopia • Insomnia, anxiety, difficulty in concentration • Memory loss Later signs-symptoms • Classic triad: oculomotor abnormalities, cerebellar dysfunc- tion (ataxia) and confusion • Quiet global confusion with disorientation in time/place • Confabulation/hallucinations • Onset of coma *Patients may present with different combinations of symptoms and signs

Random:

Explanation for incorrect options:- Option: A. Glucagon IV Glucagon increases blood glucose concentration and treats severe hypoglycemia. Glucagon acts only on liver glycogen, converting it to glucose. Glucagon administered through a parenteral route relaxes the smooth muscle of the stomach, duodenum, small bowel, and colon. Option: B . Pyridoxine Hydrochloride Injection may be administered intramuscularly or intravenously. In cases of dietary deficiency, the dosage is 10 to 20 mg daily for 3 weeks. Follow-up treatment is recommended daily for several weeks with an oral therapeutic multivitamin. Option: D. IV folic acid

options.label: C
options.text: Taking disulfiram and alcohol, the patient feels drowsy, has chest discomfort, respiratory depression

questions.correct_answer: C. Taking disulfiram and alcohol, the patient feels drowsy, has chest discomfort, respiratory depression
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Taking disulfiram and alcohol, the patient feels drowsy, has chest discomfort, respiratory depression Option: C. Taking disulfiram and alcohol, patient feel drowsy, chest discomfort, and respiratory depression is the accurate answer

Highyeild:

Disulfiram Inhibits enzyme aldehyde dehydrogenase enzyme inhibition irreversible(suicide inhibition) Disulfiram aversion therapy is indicated in abstinent subjects who sincerely desire to leave the habit and are highly motivated to quit alcohol. Raised acetaldehyde leads to highly distressing symptoms like flushing, throbbing headache, and uneasiness. Duration 1-4hrs Dose 500mg/day first week, then 250mg daily. Sensitization to alcohol develops after 2–3 hours of the first dose, reaches its peak at ~12 hours, and lasts for 7–14 days after stopping it because inhibition of aldehyde dehydrogenase with disulfiram is irreversible. Synthesis of fresh enzymes is required for the return of activity. The distressing symptoms reinforce the subject’s resolve not to drink if he drinks a little bit. The subject should be cautioned to avoid alcohol altogether.

questions.text: Which of the following drug used for Alcohol detoxification blocks the endorphin activation properties of alcohol?
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Naltrexone Naltrexone hydrochloride is a relatively pure and long-lasting opioid antagonist. Oral naltrexone has been used to treat opioid dependence for many years and has been approved to treat alcohol use disorders (AUDs).

Highyeild:

Naltrexone is an opioid receptor antagonist that blocks the endorphin activation properties of alcohol. Chronic administration of naltrexone decreased the rate of relapse to heavy drinking in randomized clinical trials.
